author: @EranM
text: Children, when you see sentdex struggle in 9:11, always remember... Writing too complicated math expression is no no. Use the following breaks: def best_fit_slope(xs, ys):     numerator = (np.mean(xs)*np.mean(ys)) - np.mean(xs*ys)     denominator = np.mean(xs)**2 - np.mean(xs**2)     return numerator/denominator  Love you sentdex! keep up the good work!

author: @devainpalbansal814
text: to avoid confusion, it is better to do  def best_fit_line(x, y):     m = mean(x)*mean(y)     m = (m - mean(x*y))     m = (m/((mean(x))**2 - mean(x**2)))     return m

author: @ShantanuBhadoria
text: mean(xs)*mean(xs) will cause the mean(xs) to be evaluated twice. Use mean(xs)**2 as its more efficient.

author: @mamazu1995
text: I have a few things to comment actually. I have to admit that implementing this is not easy but the way you did is indeed quite confusing because your code is just basically a one-line return value tried to write nicely. 1. Why don't you avoid the confusion with the division and split this up into numerator and denominator and then returned numerator/denominator to make it clearer? If you do it like that you wouldn't need a single bracket (except for function calls) 2. Why don't you save the mean of x in a variable? You use it three times in your code. I don't know how smart the mean function is but with a bigger dataset, it would be probably be better to calculate it once and reuse it. 3. I know that this is not a real issue, but why do you name the parameters of the function the same as the variables you have in the global scope. I know that the parameters take precedence over the global variables but this encourages shadowing. Just as a side note.  But otherwise I like your style of programming and programming python make it look elegant.
